data.title: ENGLISH CRICKET TEAM IN TASMANIA
data.meta_description: To Mr. Thomas Westbrook belongs the honour of taking the first steps to induce an English team to visit Tasmania. In 1862 that gentleman entered into ...
data.text:
On this Page 2

ENGLISHI CRICKET TEAM IN

TASMANIA

\ ---- --*--

A fISTOR?COAL SKETOIl.

1862 TO 190S.

("Ly J.J.'C., in the "Mercury.")'

II. 11 i :SITEPI'ENSON'S 'h. M-1802.

To IMr. Thomas W*estbrook belongs the

honour of taking the first steps to in

duce an, Englishl team to visit 'I'asmania,

ii 18ii2 that gentletman entered into

ncgotiations wvith lMessrs. Spiers and

'Pond for a visit, frpm II. 11. 8tephen

sot's eleven. A reply being received. a

public meeting was convened, and Mr.

John Davies, the proprietor of the "Ho

"ba.rt Town Mercury," was requested to

.proceedl to 1etlbourne to effeect the ne

cessary arriatgemients for a game to be

lilayed in Hobart. 'Mr. Davies proceeded

'to lIelbourne, and the "Argus" a few

days aftert stated:-"Our Tasmanian

readers will be glad to learn that Mr.

'Davies, of the 'Hlobart Town Mercury,'

has succeedtld in effecting an arrange

ment with Messrs. Spiers and Pond, for

a visit of the All-England Eleven to

Tasmania." The Englishmen arrived cc

dLaunceston fromt Melbourne by the

stetuner Royal Shepherd on 'WVednesday,

vFebruary '11, 1602.

The itatch against 22 of Tasmania

was played on February 21, 22, and 24.

The Tasuanian team consisted of the

'following players:--'. -Westbrook, l)Du

maresq, Walker, Perry, Spicer, Brooks,

Still, Tabart, T. Whitesides, Taylor, Cox,

:i. Watson, Mlace, Boon, Patterson, Side.

bottom, Dargarville, H. Lette, Marsha.ll,

Jamitson, B. IWatson, and Orford. Th'e

'English team consisted of lddison, E.

Stephenson, Priflith, Caffyn, H. 1. Ste-.

phentson .(captain), ,Hearne, Bennett,

Sewell, Wells, Mfortlock, and Mudie. Tilhe

Englishmen won by four wickets, the

scores reading:---Tasmania, 107 and 141;

Englandd.17-6 and 7'5 for six wickets.

Even in those days our Ibowlers had some

idea of "off" theory-very much "off"

us lhere were no fewer than 20.. wides

sent down-'1 in the first and 4 in the

second innings. In the first innings of

IEngland, E. 'tophenson top-scored with

00, and in the second Griflith was high.

est with 36. Taobart, in the first innings

of Tasmania, was the leading rungetter

with '15, and in the second innings T.

'Whitesides made- 60 before he .was

bowled by II. I. Stephenson. The ac

count of 'Tasmania's second innings stat

ed that "Tabart and dumaresq maide

very fair scores, but it was owing to

the cool and cautious play of W'Whitesides

that the score of the Twenty-two for

ithe second innings presented such a re

spectable number. His - batting and de

fence were splendid. Caffyn,' lddison,

tand Bennett in vain tried to strike his

wicket, and it ivas not until he had kept

his post four hours that he at last suc

cutembed to a terrific ball from H. -1.

Stephenson. As lie left the wicket le

was loudly cheered by his fellow-cricket

ers and the spectators. The All-Engliind

Eleven, with chiralric feeling, gave most

'unnmistakable demnonstrations of (their

admiration of his play. To this Tasma

nian plater belongs the proud distinc

tion of having made the highest score

effected by any colonial player in any

of the matches which have as yet been

phsyed with the All-England Eleven."

Whitesides hit three 4's, one 3. seven 2's,

and twenty-one singles.

In the bowvling department the work

for Tasmania was chiefly done in the

'first innings by Still, one for 37 (eight

-wides); Spicer, five for 60 (three wides);

and the captain, W. V. . Walker, one for

43. In the second innings Spicer, three

for 30 (four wides), and 'Walker, three

for 30, were the successful Tasmanian

bowlers. England's bowlers in the first

innings were Caffyn (round arm), five

for 37. and Iddison (slow underhand),

eight for 32. In the second innings Caf

dyn took three for 39; Iddison,. eleven

for 63; Bennett, one for 13; Sewell, one

for 13 ;and H..I. Stephenson, one for 2,

Mr. T. Hewitt umpired for Tasmania,

and Mr. (Laurence for England. The

scorers were IMessrs. F. C. Tribe (Eng

land) and G. Collins (Tasmania).

A one-day match between mixed

teams chosen by II. H. Stephenson and

E. Stephenson was also played. the

former scoring 80 and 22 for five wickets

and the latter 100. This match was unw.

pired by Messrs. C. B. Allison and P.

Facy, the latter the father of the pre

sent secretary of the Tasmanian Cricket

Association.

W.. G. G?ACEAES TEA-1 -1874.

In February, 1874, . Grace's first Eng

lish team included t'asmania in their

progratnue, and 'on the 26th, 27th,

and .29th of that month played a

Northern Tasmanian Twenty-two at

iLaunceston, and beat them by an lin

nings and 32 runs--247 'gainst 90. and

123. amonlgst the northerners were J.

G. Davies, W II. l VWalker (who acted as

captain), G. H. Bailey, C. W. Butler, E.

11. Butler, and If. V. Bayly. , The fea

ture of the Tasm?nnian batting were the

scores of John Lord, who played very

,finely for 34 and 30. At .his second ef

-ort he scored 14 offl four balls. He andt

E. d?. Butler were thie only ones who

got into double figures in the first ini.

nitgs. Butler played free and good cric.

ket for 1. There were no fewer than

tet "ducks," due principally to the ef

fectiveness of Soutlherton's slows. Be

sides Lord, J. Arthur, 32, and G. 1l. Bai

ley (still an active cricketer), 12, reach

ed double figure distinction in the second

i.nings.Thele leading scorers for England

were--Oseroft 09, G. F. Grace 45. W.

G. Grace 33, Jupp, 33, sM'Ittyre 2'. and

Greenwood 10. Tile Tasmanian bowling

iwas done by G. H. Bailey, two for 062;

3f. HI. Butler, one for 38; 'If. V. Bayly,

two for 04-; T..BHogg, three for 42; and

Wi. 'iI. 'Walker, one for 25. 1-H. V. Bayly

in his,lirst eight overs bowled seveu

aoideens, and took one wicket for one

run. For England the destruction was

swroughlt by Lillywldhte. five for 41 and

oile for 32; douthern; thirteen for 33

and ten for 39; add W. G. Grace (second

innmings only), nine for 48.

On'March 3, 4, and 5, the match at

Hobart was against 22 of Southern Tws

mania (with some nortlhern players in

eluded), when the latter were defeated

by eighlt wickets. The home players

sncored 105 and 198. and the English

representotives 308 and 25 for two wic

kets. In this matochl G. F. Grace made

the largest score (154) ever made up

to thmat time in Tasmania in atty first

class match. He hit one 0. Further

morc, the score was the largest nmde

by any player during thie three visits

by Englishi teams to Australia (Parr's

1804 team did not visit Tasmania). and

the largest ot record obtained even in

G-reat lIritain against .iany teantn of 22.

As aO illustra-tion o, the \vicissitudes of

cricket, it may be added thlmt in the

second inninigs G. F. Graice scored only

a single, being bowled by EIi. 11. hut

ler amidst great excitcement amortgst

the onlookers. Oseroft, who lilt a sixer,

inade 41, Ii. Jupip 44, \V. G. Grace (one

six) 29, A. Greenwood 28, antd iR. Ilutm

plrey 20.: Sixes were lbit in Tasmna

inia's first inuings by J. G. Davies (to

leg off Lillywhrvite) and WV. II. Walker

(off W\. G. Grace), blle batstiein namIed

scoring 13 and 34 resplectively. Others

who did well iil the first inninlgs were

it. Barnes (28), T. Wlhites-ides (23). E.

Lucas (22), C. J. M3axwell (ll); .and

1t. C. Cutthbcrt (11). In tIlie second

innings \V. II. Walker aroused tue en

thusiasm of the onlookers by hitting two

successive balls from W. G. Grace out

or the ground in a contribution of IS.

E. Whitesides scored 35, J. Arthur 31,

E. Lucas.31, MLajor Gox 23 not out, and

C. W. Butler 13. The bowlirng for En0

)and was chiefly done by Lillywhite

(nine for 70 and five for 65), W. G.

-?LGre .(e~gaOr,.Ri .d.f ..fogO4);, 24'JaI

tyre, (one for 20 amd one for 15); 0.

I. Grace (first innings, one for 27),

BRou1t (first innings, one for 11), and

Gilbert (second intuings, eight for 47)

tfite Tasmanian bowling \wias performed

Rby H. V. Bayly (seven for 100), E. II.

Butter (one for S f .,al" n; for 12), W.

H. Walker (1% isr ti), R. Iarnes

(none for .). . It.ley (sone for' 30),

H. W'i :,... , ...o for o), and J. It.

MWalsie i1.,,..: ir 12).

Tre vit "i° :e 1874 teamn aroused in

usual cnthae.itaa t.hroughout Tasma?iia,

and :::lr3 social functions were carried

out is hoi,our of the Englishmen, in

cludarrr l?oducciont of lthe opera "'Ma

ritasn. ' a; th 'T'own Hall, llobaart. lHis

r'txeli:.:v Gtverno l)Du Cane was pre

sent at :e?airly all of these, and pre

sidesr at the luncheon on the ground,

whens Ii: pr'eented John Lord with a bat'

for his play in the matcih at Launces

ton; also one to E. Lucas for highest

score at Hobart. lion. '. O. Fysi

Itav: . II . L J3,t]y , bat for iis 'ad

mirable bowling,"' anu J. Martin (Liaun-i

ceston) was the recupient of a bat from

Messrs. . J. alch and Sons for lhis "ex

cellent long-stopping." Thel scorers in

the aunteh at Ilobkrt were Messrs. E. H.

Uawson and A . Ci. Olitpman.

iORD 0 HIAIttRIS' TEAML -1879.

Lord .larris' 1870 combina.tion airang

ad for a three dlays' match iut Hobarc

DIo January 9, 10, and 11, but owing to

the superiority in thle play of the visit

ors it wae ende.d in two days. The

reSpult ita' as wisn for Enslaend by six

wickets, due mauinly to toe batting of

A. N. ltoro'nby. 1"t not out). Lord Itsar

ris, A. I'. Lucas, and George Ulyett,

and the bowling of Emeuncet and Ulyett.

Valdker (S and 33), J. G. Davies (13

Sanld 23), E. J. trconutn (27), and J. Ait

kesn (17) were the leading scorers for

South' Tasmania. Our bowlers did pre'ly

Well. 11V. V. Bayly took t'hree for i5,

and two for 30, and E. T. Boddam four

for 65 and one for 32. The scores were

-Englalid, 133 and 94 for four wickets;

South Tasmania, S2 and 142. '

During tlhe visit of Lord Harris' teacm

. Ir. David Baleln1,b the present manag

i" igcdirector. of bhy C(osnimercial Bank

of Tiisanliia, received a nasty WbloO over

Shl eye yfront a ball bowled by Uljyett.

'The mlatch was finished 'on the Friday,

ind on the following afternuooen Ulyett

and Emmet.t were bowling to several of

thI Tasmtanians on ai sticky wicket on

bhe old lower grisund. Mr. Bairclay

went to pick up' a bat frodn the ground,

ve,,:,.. he met' with the accident, tho

force with inhidi the ball strtigk him

c.rusing 'the blood to flow freely down

hist fade. ':llie wsiter (.then a mere lad)

was on blh old lower ground at the

'time, and r6members the ineident being

Srecorded in pencil in a corner in bthe

pavilion, where thee -corers used to sit..

On that same -afternoon Ulyett and Em-'

S-sett induced several of those who were

batting (1the latI Mr. E. J. Freeman

and Mr. R. G. Kirby among the ttnim

ber) to put some coins on the "stoomps"

o ' give them soumetlhing to "ba-al at."

An'd they hilt the stumps pretty often

when coins were used as bails.

Time only permnitted of ai one-day

matelh by Lord HarriS' eleven at Laun

cestoll on Monday, January 13, the re

sult, ias might be expected, being incon

elusive. The nortlhern eighrten only got

41 and 38 for sevesn wickets, Major Cox,

who got 18 ini the first- innings, being

the solitary double-figure scorer. aEu

inett (twelve for 20) anid. Ulyet (five

for 22) were the English bowlers. Loi-d

lIarris' teasm totalled 212-Penst 53,Lord

Iarris 33, Absdlon 32, Emmett 24, Uly

ett' 22, .Hone 12. For "bthe inortheiners

T. Hogg (one for 03), Atkinson (two for

35), Loughnasl (one foi. 23), W. I-logg

(one for 30), Douglas (one for nought),

and Perguson (four for 33) were the

successful trundlers.

liON. IVO BLIGH'S TEAM--1883.

Shaw's 1881-2 teans did not touneh Tas

anania, but on January 12 and 13, 1883,

t?he' Ilon. Ivo Bligh's teani visited Ho

bart, and played a maatch against 18 of

Southern T'asmanlia on tthe' present asso

ciation ground. The locals sco'ed 82

and 95, and Englad England 110 and 18 for

three wickets;, the latter tilus winning

'by sveli wickets. The Tasmanlian bats

men were unable to make much head

way against A. G. Steel (six for 42), and

Morley (four for 17), and Bates (four

for 19), the bowling being backed up

'by brillianrt fielding atid superb wicket

keeping by E. F. S. Tylecote. J. G.

Davies, who captained the southerners,

was chief scorer in the first innings

witll 23, and S. K. Chapman (10) was

Isis nearest attendant. IH. V. Bayly was

'the other double-figure mtean. England's

small score in treir first batting ven

'bure was primarily due' to the fine bowl

ing of T. Kendall, who took six wic

kets for 55 runs. I-I. V. Bayly, though

lie bowled well, c?ly got one for 24, and

E. Maaxwell secured thhree for 21. Hon.

Ivo Blight (32), A. G. Steel (21), VW.

Barnes (15), and G. B. Studd (11) were

the best scorers for England. In the

southern second innings Arthur made

14, C. Maaxwell 14, C. M'AIllen 14, and

G. Gatehouse 10. The bowling for Eng

land was pmfonnced by Morley (nine for

40) and Steel (seven for 41). In the

EEnglisimen's second innings Steel (30

iot out). Barlow (16), and W. W. Read~

(14 not out) did nearly all tise rut

getting. I. V. Banyly obtained two wic.

kets for 12 runs, and Kendall one for

Before coming to IIobart the Honu.

vno. Blighl's Eleven met a Northern

Eighteeu, who were assisted by T. Ken

dall (then in the zenith of his bowline

formn) on January 8, 9, and 10, and thle

Englishmcen von by an innings and 75

runs. The home players in their first

batting venture were dismissed for 114

-(O. G. Douglas 29, I. Watson 17, F.

C. Hobkirk 12), but did worse at the

second attempt, when they only man

aged a total of 81 (0. G. Douglas 16,

If. Stubbs 10, and J. Mansfield 14). The

'English Elevesn scored 270 (C. T. Studd

run out 99, A. G. Steel 30 not out, IHon.

Ivo Bligh. 34, Barlow 20, Bates 25, Tlyle.

cote 10). Kendall took five wickets for

S104; Oldmeadoev, three for 17; and HR.

Sams, one for 30. The Einglisht bowlers

rer-e-A. G. Steel, four for 30 and ten

for 33; Batei, tlhree fo 1'5 and thlree

for 14; C. T. Studdl, one for 23; Barnes,

six for 25 and one for 13; Barlow, twvo

for 14 and two for 24.

VIRNON'S TDAIM.-18S8.

Five years elapsed before another

English team chlse this way. It Janu

o'ry. 1883, Venion's elevels played a

i? -" '- • ":" . .. r ?

drawn game at Launceston against a

Northern eighteen, which included K.

'Burn. The Englishmen, batting first,

got 195, A. E. 3toddart making 01, and

T. C. O'Brien 35 not out. Northern

Tlasimania responded with 162 (Windsor

20!, K. 'Burn t.. . Savigny 20, \\. L.

Sidebottom 12, I. Ilitchie 13, and L.

R. Sams 10).' In their ,second innings

England loa, three for 27.

At Latrobe on January 16 and 17 a

coastal twenty-two iwere encountered,

,when the Englishmen won by an in

nings, and 134 runs--71 against 62 and

95.. Atotwell made 122 for England be

fore he was bowled by Atkinson, and

Stoddart was run out for 40.

On Friday, January 20, and Saturday,

January 21. the teasn were opposed at

HIobart by an eighteen representing

Southern 'Tasmania. the contest being

drawn. Our planyers only made 59 in

their first innings. Kendall (9) was the

highest scorer. R. Peel took. elevent

wickets for 21 runs, and Beaumont four

for 209. In their second essay Southl

:Tasmania made 91 for seven wickets.

T. ,tlyan 26, W. Abbott 17, C. M1'Allen

-14, J. G. Davies 12i and "simdries" 20,

did the best run-getting. The English

men's' only effort with the bat produced

'147 runs. The highest scorers were Rl.

Peel 52, R. Abel 37, W. W. Read 18, and

T. Q. O'Brien 13. T. Kendall, six for

57, and E. Maxwell, four for 50, got the

wickets for. South Tasmania.

On Jarinuary 20, 27. and 28 a match

.England v. Tasmania (18) was played

at Hobart. and again the resutlt was in

conclusive, from the fact that the Tas

manians played better than in the pre

vious games. They got rid of the Eng

lishnien for 2097, of which R.'Peel made

1]19, W. W. Read 3S; 3. Rawlin 34, T. C.

O'Brien 28, A. E. Stoddart 26, and W.

Attewell 0d, T. Kendall, three for 91;

E. Maxwell, three for 68OS; J. Binghaam,

one .for 43; and T. P. Ryan, three for

4,1. were the successful bowlers. Tas

mania scored 405 for the loss of thirteen

.wickets. K. E: Burn shade 99 (? 100).

Although the scorers .had only 99 down

to Burn, several of the spectators who

kept scoring caids agreed that he made

a century. The matter was discussed

at the lunch interval, and it was gene

rally held that Buirn was. entitled to

century distinction. The batsman him

self counted each run lie made on the

second day (34), having on the pre

vious day made 10 not out. L. .I.

Mitcleod 50. V. W. L. Sidebottoin 42, G.

Gatehouse 42, E. II. Butler 30, W. Ab

bott 27, J. G. Davies 18, O. W. Butler lb.

and "'sundries" 34 scored well for Tas

'fania. Burn was the recipient of 'a testi

monial for his fine batting.

LORD 6AIIEFFIDLD'S -AtAM.--1892.

After Vernon's eeamsn?came Lord Shef

field's combination .in! 1892, headed by

the "Grand Old 'lhn;" W. G. Grace.

They played a 'twelve-man matceh

against eighteen of Southern Tasmania

at Hobart on March 4, 5, and 7. iH.

Wilson, J. Savigny, and W. H. Savignsy,

of Launceston, were included in the

Southern team, which was captained by

K. E. Burn. Grace won the toss, and

England batted, their first innings pro

ducing 243 runs. Stoddar't was top

scorer. with 84 not out, made by bril

liant cricket. Peel 32, Grace -, Phil

lipson 27, Radcliff 23, Maurice Read 13,

and G. Lolimann 13, were the otlier chief

runs-getters. The feature of the South

erners' out-cricket was the howling of

T. Kendall, who sent down 200 balls for

21 maideis,- 70 runs, 7 wickets; his vie

tims being..Grace, Abel; Maurice Read,

Radcliffe, Bean, Attewell. and Sharp.' It

was in this innings that John Watt

bowled his "donkey-drops" to Geeo. Loh

mann, who deliberately played the ball

with his 'pads, but eventually the re

sourceful WVitt sent down one 'that broke

round Lohmann's legs, and knocked down

the middle stump. Some people. .who

saw this mnatch have. been heard to say

that Stoddart . hit Watt out of the

ground for six (ine fact, ,the bowler him

seclf thinks this was 'thile case), but the

records of the play show that Stoddart

made "the finest hit of the match, driv

ing Watt right over the boundary rail

at the northern end for five, following

it up with another of a similar descrip

tion to leg in the next over." ' Watt

bowled 150 balls for seven maidensi; 63

runs, 2 wickets, Lolnnann and Peel being

his victims. The Tasmainians made a

poor display in their first innings, scoring

only 76' off the blt, and with 10 sun

dries, the total was 85. W. Ii. Savigny

was the highest scorer, with 15, the other

doubles being J. Bingham and J. Watt,

whib each made 10. Lolimann had quite

a feast of wickets, taking twelve for 50,

the other five going to e4ittevell at an

expense of 25 runs. The second batting?

essay of our representgtives showed

some improvement, 137 being on the

board when the last wicket fell, which

gave the victory to the Englishmen by

an innings and 21 runs. J. H. Savigny

led the way with 35; and was closely fol

lowed by K. E.. Biit wi th 31. Gee.

Vautia got 190; and 'C:'W. Butler con

tributed a dozen. Lohmann put up an

other remarkable bdwling record in tak

ing thirteen wickets for 53 runs. Atte

well obtained three for 38, and Sharpe

one dor 21. Johnnie 'Briggs (whose clever

catching of Burn is not likely to be for

gotten) also bowled, but failed to secure

a wicket. A testimonial of five guineas

eas made to Tom Kendlall for his line

bowling against the Engolishmen.

When Lofd Shleffield's team met Nor

thern Tasmansia at Launceston on 7darch

10, 11, and 12 the hlome side were as

sisted by irve Southelcrners, namely G.

Gatehouse, C. J. Eady, G. Vautin, C.

-3Allen, and T. Kendall. The game was

drawn. Enigland put up a to'tal of 400

(feIaurice Read 95, Briggs 74, Attewell 50,

Stoddart 47, Lohlmann 43, Grace 22,

Siharpe (not out) 18, Bean 17, M'Gregor

12, Peel 10). Most of the wickets were

sec'red by IH. ("Blundell'') Wilson, six

for 109. Windsor took one for 78, Ken

dall one for 86, N. Reeock two for 45, and

W. LI. Sidebottom one for125. The Tas

manians niade 131 (W. L. Sidhbottom 33,

Geo. ITH. Bailey 25, G, Vautin 22, O. Doug

las 10, N. Rock 10), and in the follo---on

smade 135 feor six wickets (G. Vautin 38,

HII. Wilson not out 33, W. L. Sideot~tom

not out 24, J. It. Savigny 13). In tas

mania's first innings the wicket-takers

were Grace two for 25, Phillipson three

for 15, Lohmann four for 51, Attewell

seven for 34.

sTODDART'S Tc.&M.--1895.

Unseasonaeblo weather emilitated

against thie success of the match played

-by Stolddart's teaim at BJohart on kMarch

'14, 15, and 10, 1595, against fifteen of

Soutlern Tasmania. C. J. Iady (Ifive

for 60) and J. Binghlim ('four for 23),

bowling unchanged, dlismissed the visi

tors for 01 I(Stodldart 21, A. Ward 14,

and A. C. Miaelaren 14). Tihe bhone

players ecored 180. ,Sid. Howe made

51 not out, and won a trophy for the

Iiglhest score presented by ?ir. Noel

,White. Others who attatined double

figure distinction were C. J. Eady 35, E.

ratxiell 18, G. Gatehlouse 117, K. 1. Burn

1-, alnd J. Watt 12. There were 17

sundries. England's bowling was prin

eip:lly dlone bly F. U. J. Ford (nine for

56) and 'Brockwell (four for 50).

Stoddart's 1S9 team, like some of ito

predecessors, halted at Iaunceston for

a match before fulfilling their IIobart

enggeomments. They played at the

nortliern capital on March 9, II, and 12,

and the umatchc 'was left ursfinished. The

northern 18 scored 178 (N. I. West

brook 5), W. ll.Saevigny 22, J. S.

Clemmons (now Senator, and Tasmania's

representative on the board of control)

17, H. Ewart 18, C. Taylor 10, J. YMar

tin 13) and 219 for .thirteen wickets (NT.

8I. Woestbrook 40, B. A. Windsor 38, I-H.

WVilson 30, R. Fernandes 31 not out, L.

farms 18, J. .'Wall 12). In the first

inlwash 0of ,he nortlhersrea. Lockwood

took two .rickets fiur '29 runs, dmum

phreys ,(slow lobs) ten for D8, and

Brockwell four for 16;. and in the se

cond, Brockwell obtained two for 37,

Lockwood three for 27, Stodart one for

22, Ford five for 'IS, and 'Phillipson one

for 13. The Englishmen's i'r:t and

only innings realised 291 ruts, the prin.

cipal contributors to which were Stod

dart 73 not out, lIrockwell 60,, J. T'.

Brown 35, A. C. Maclaren 24, *W. linmph

reys 21, and L. II. Gay '13. The wickets

for Nortier3u Tasmania were secured by

Windsor fide for 1'17, N. Rlock three for

73, und H. Wilson one for 35.

There was an interval of nine years

,before another English teami visited Ta.s

mania, namnely, the Marylebone U.C.

team, c.ptained by P. F. WYarner. They

,played,. for the first time on record, an

eloven of Tasnmania at Hobart on Janu

ary 25 and 26, 1904. The islanders

gained a lead on the first innings by six

runs, scoring 101 against 185. In their

second innings the -Englishmen dealt

rather severely with the bowling, Bosan

quet, who made 124 not out, being con

temptuous in his treatment of it, hit

ting four fives and eighteen fours. Tas

mania lost one wicket for 63 runs in

their second essay, and the maitch was

drawn. The Englishmen closed at 354

for four wickets. Lilley 35, R. E. Fos

ter 43 and 23, Tyldesley 4 and 85, Knight

10 and 45 not out, Bosanquet 35 and

124 not out, Relf 24, Wrner 20- and

(14, did the scoring for England. R.

-1lawson 29 aInd 37 not out, O. Douglas

38, N. Dodds 24 and 2 not out, 0. ;J.

Eady 16, K. Burn 23 not out and 24, D.

R. Smith 113, and D. Paton 18, were the

chief scorers for Tasmania. Arnold

four fo ,44, Fielder one for .18, Relf one

for 20, Bosanquet one for 55, and Rhodes

tivo for 52, did the bowling for England.

The regular bowlers were not tried in

Tasmania's second innings. Bady (three

for 40 and none for 80), Smith (three

for 42 and one for 97), Windsor (three

for 6S and three for 00), were the suc

cessful trundlers for Tasnlania. At the

conclusion of the matelh the English cap

tain ('Mr. P. F. 'Warner) spoke in high

praise of the umpiring, iand, personally

addres.ing the two honorary officials

(,Messr.. John VWatt and Charles 'tMAl:

len), said "lie wished the utitpiring

throughout Australia had been as good

as, it had been at Hobart." The two

olleials, it unmay be added, are amongst

the finest judges of the. game to be

found in Australia.

The retprn inatch played at Launces

ton by Warner's team will be ever

memoraole in the annals of cricket in

Tasmania. It is closely associated with

the names of J.41. Savigny and 0. Doug

las. In their first innings the Tasma

nians were dismissed for 141, Dodds

playing fine, free cricket for 48. Wind

sor batted nicely for 33, and there was

nothing wrong with N. i. Westlbrook's

score of 26. Hirst, five for 37; 'Fielder,

three for 44; and Arnold, two for 10,

took the wickets for the visitors. Thei

Englishmen's first innings total of 353

included a fine 134 by Hayward. Hlirs,

got 51, Rhodes 39, Lilley 37 not out,

1"iclder 23, and Strudwick 21. Smith,

four for 'H11; Windsor, four for 106, and

Addison, one for, 04;, were tlhe-successful

Tasmanian trundlers. In their second

essay with the bat the Tasmanians ut

terly surprised the Enoglishmen by scor

ing 259 for three wickets. J. H. Sav

igny; (who did not score in the, first

innings). made 464 not out, and 0. Doug

las (whose first innings score was only

a single) totted up 59. Writing of the

Tasmanian tbur, and of this match in

particular, P. F. WýVrner, in his book,

"How we Recovered the Ashes," says:

"Hayward played a superb innings of

134, but the most noteworthy batting

was by Savigny, 'whose 51i4 not out was,

except for a comparatively easy chance

to Lilley at mid-off, quite faultless. He

had strokes all round the wicket, being

especially strong in the off drive, and he

watched the ball closely. Hirst, -who

uhad a good bowl at him, told me lie was

a really high-class batsman. Our long

lead on the first .innings gave hopes of

a victory, but Savigny and 'Douglas quite

upset all our calculations by putting on

202 for the dirst wicket--a feat which

not even that famdus pair, Trumper and

Duff. dpproached. iDouglas,' a left-hand-.

ed batsman, with all the virtues of a

Scotton or a Barlow, was batting over

four hours. LHis defence was magnilf

cent, but lie entirely ignored the slow

long-lop. (His ltience was invaluable,

Ibut it was, to say the least of it, mono

tonous . . Tasnmania can boast of

many good 'cricketers, and the form

shown in the two miatches we played was

a great deal better than' we had been

led to expect. Orieketers like Windsor,

Savigny, Dodds, Hlwson, and Douglas

would strengthen almost any eleven.

-Most enjoyable in every 'way was our

stay in the lovely island,, and future

teams to Australia should take care to

include Tasmania in their programme."
